fields.description:
The euserv-* commands do not have a replacement for the following euca-describe-services functionality:

{code}
#
# euca-describe-services -E real-cc-1
warning: euca-describe-services is deprecated; use ``euserv-describe-services'' instead
SERVICE	cluster           	real      	real-cc-1            	NOTREADY	119 	http://10.111.5.9:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:real:cluster:real-cc-1/
ERROR	cluster           	real      	real-cc-1            	com.eucalyptus.ws.EucalyptusRemoteFault: Action:ProblemAction Code:soapenv:Server Id:RelatesTo Error: Operation Not Found
SERVICEEVENT	2369c1ba-4e22-4186-bfd2-66ca382f165c	arn:euca:eucalyptus:real:cluster:real-cc-1/
SERVICEEVENT	2369c1ba-4e22-4186-bfd2-66ca382f165c	ERROR
SERVICEEVENT	2369c1ba-4e22-4186-bfd2-66ca382f165c	Fri Apr 01 17:29:39 PDT 2016
SERVICEEVENT	2369c1ba-4e22-4186-bfd2-66ca382f165c	com.eucalyptus.ws.EucalyptusRemoteFault: Action:ProblemAction Code:soapenv:Server Id:RelatesTo Error: Operation Not Found
#
#
{code}

which shows the errors for the service.

comments.body: We withheld this in favour of the new DescribeEvents interface in 4.2, but that feature was not completed in time for that release.

The general events mechanism was not added in 4.3 so we will not have a way to view service events if we remove euca-describe-services.

Some potential options for 4.3. are:

# retain the existing euca-describe-services command
# update euserv-describe-services to include service events
# add a new euserv command for "legacy" events
# ensure service errors are logged (periodically) so there is some mechanism for service debugging

The properties for events in the new feature are:

# Unique identifier – globally unique identifier for a single event occurance
# Timestamp – time on originating host at which event occurred
# Service – the name of the service that created the event as registered in the system via standard Eucalyptus service registration operations
# Component – the component type of the source service (e.g. compute, objectstorage, storage, cloudwatch, etc)
# Host IP/dns name – host where the event occurred as used in the registration entry
# Description – Free-form text description
# Severity - INFO|WARN|ERROR|CRITICAL
# (OPTIONAL) Event Code -- A numeric code to identify the event type if applicable (for consistent reporting)
# (OPTIONAL) Related Resource (instanceId, volumeId, etc) – The resource involved in the event, as applicable. An instanceId might be applicable for an event involving a failed vol attachment
# (OPTIONAL) Originating correlationId – The correlationId of the request that triggered the event (e.g a runInstance correlationId)

so aside from the optional properties there appears to be a one-to-one correspondence.

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/ES/Architecture%3A+Eucalyptus+System+Events
https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/ES/Eucalyptus+Events+Data+Structure
Did we reach a conclusion on how to proceed with this one or do we need to discuss this further, [~gholms]?

For this I wrote a new command for the admin tool suite called {{euserv-describe-events}}, a façade that makes our existing event functionality look like the future [System Events|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/ES/Architecture%3A+Eucalyptus+System+Events] feature is planned to work.  There are three major consumers of the data for this command:

# Shell scripts that handle input line-by-line
# Smarter scripts that can handle data structures
# Humans

We can satisfy both of the latter two by using YAML, which yields surprisingly readable output that is still possible for smart scripts that can read multi-line data structures to interpret:

{code}
# euserv-describe-events
events:
- timestamp: 2016-06-20 16:16:08
  severity: INFO
  id: e03904e5-2048-4c90-bba2-5faea0785ef7
  subject-type: node
  subject-name: 10.111.1.15
  subject-host: 10.111.1.15
  subject-arn: arn:euca:bootstrap:one:node:10.111.1.15/
  message: |-
    the node is operating normally
    Found service status for 10.111.1.15: ENABLED
- timestamp: 2016-06-27 17:37:57
  severity: ERROR
  id: 31ce8935-7431-4c1e-aab1-bf77519ba0a8
  subject-type: node
  subject-name: 10.111.5.50
  subject-host: 10.111.5.50
  subject-arn: arn:euca:bootstrap:two:node:10.111.5.50/
  message: |-
    Error occurred in transport
- timestamp: 2016-06-28 07:00:17
  severity: ERROR
  id: 1e012645-3fef-44e0-a382-c48fd2374ce9
  subject-type: node
  subject-name: 10.111.5.50
  subject-host: 10.111.5.50
  subject-arn: arn:euca:bootstrap:two:node:10.111.5.50/
{code}

For scripts that want line-by-line data we have a {{--format oneline}} option:

{code}
# euserv-describe-events --format oneline
2016-06-20 16:16:08 INFO node 10.111.1.15 the node is operating normally\nFound service status for 10.111.1.15: ENABLED
2016-06-27 17:37:57 ERROR node 10.111.5.50 Error occurred in transport
2016-06-28 07:00:17 ERROR node 10.111.5.50 
{code}

I initially used a dedicated --oneline option for this, but using a generic --format option that takes a format as input means we can seamlessly add on other formats in the future.  It also gave it a means for users to supply their own output formats like this:

{code}
# euserv-describe-events --format 'format:{timestamp} {subject-name} {message}'
2016-06-20 16:16:08 10.111.1.15 the node is operating normally\nFound service status for 10.111.1.15: ENABLED
2016-06-27 17:37:57 10.111.5.50 Error occurred in transport
2016-06-28 07:00:17 10.111.5.50 
{code}

In its current form, this tool's --format option accepts three options:  {{yaml}}, {{oneline}}, and {{format:STRING}}.  By default, stack traces are hidden due to their length, but the --show-stack-traces option makes them show up if necessary.

In Eucalyptus 4.3 I intend to introduce this tool as a tech preview so we can gather feedback and make changes to it in future releases.

The complete documentation for this command is as follows:

{noformat}
EUSERV-DESCRIBE-EVENTS(1)   BSD General Commands Manual

NAME
     euserv-describe-events — Show information about service-affecting events

SYNOPSIS
     euserv-describe-events [-s] [-f FORMAT]

TECH PREVIEW
     euserv-describe-events is a technical preview.  Its name and behavior are
     subject to change without notice in future releases.

DESCRIPTION
     The euserv-describe-events utility retrieves information about service-
     affecting events in the cloud.  Events come in the form of a list, where
     each event contains one or more of the following tags:

     id              A unique ID for the event
     message         A free-form text description of the event
     severity        The message's severity (FATAL, URGENT, ERROR, WARNING,
                               INFO, DEBUG, TRACE)
     stack-trace     The stack trace, if any, corresponding to the event.  The
                               -s option is required to make this appear.
     subject-arn     The Eucalyptus ARN of the service affected by the event
     subject-name    the name of the service affected by the event
     subject-type    The type of service affected by the event
     timestamp       The date and time of the event's creation

   Optional arguments
     -f FORMAT, --format FORMAT
             Print events in a given format, where FORMAT can be one of yaml,
             oneline, and format:STRING.  See the "OUTPUT FORMATS" section for
             details about each format.  When omitted, the format defaults to
             yaml.

     -s, --show-stack-traces
             Include the stack-trace tag in events' data.  This is omitted by
             default due to its length.

     -h, --help
             Show a help message and exit without doing anything.

     -U URL, --url URL
             The URL of the service to contact.

     -I KEY_ID, --access-key-id KEY_ID
             The access key ID to use to authenticate requests.

     -S KEY. --secret-key KEY
             The secret key to use to authenticate requests.

     --security-token TOKEN
             The STS security token to use to authenticate requests.

     --region USER@REGION
             The user and/or region name to use when looking up configuration
             file data.

     --debug
             Show debugging output when running.

     --debugger
             Launch an interactive epdb or pdb debugger after encountering an
             error.

     --version
             show the program's version and exit

ENVIRONMENT
     AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
             The access key ID to use when authenticating web service
             requests.  This takes precedence over and euca2ools.ini(5), but
             not -I.

     AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
             The secret key to use when authenticating web service requests.
             This takes precedence over --region and euca2ools.ini(5), but not
             -S.

     EUCA_BOOTSTRAP_URL
             The URL of the service to contact.  This takes precedence over
             --region and euca2ools.ini(5), but not -U.

OUTPUT FORMATS
     There are several built-in formats, and you can define additional formats
     using a format: string, as described below.  Here are the details of the
     built-in formats:

     ·   yaml

               events:
               - timestamp: {timestamp}
                 severity: {severity}
                 id: {id}
                 subject-type: {subject-type}
                 subject-name: {subject-name}
                 subject-host: {subject-host}
                 subject-arn: {subject-arn}
                 message: |-
                   {message}
                 stack-trace: |-
                   {stack-trace}

         This outputs block-style YAML designed to be readable by both humans
         and machines.  Tags that are empty or not defined do not appear in
         this output at all.

     ·   oneline

               {timestamp} {severity} {subject-type} {subject-name} {message}

         This is designed to be as compact as possible.

     ·   format:STRING

         The format:STRING format allows you to specify which information you
         want to show using placeholders enclosed in curly braces to indicate
         where to show the tags for each event.  For example:

               euserv-describe-events -f "format:{timestamp} {subject-name}
               {message}"

SEE ALSO
     euserv-describe-services(1), euca2ools.ini(5), eucalyptus-admin(7)

HISTORY
     The euserv-describe-events command first appeared in Eucalyptus 4.3.

NOTES
     euserv-describe-events requires access keys and knowledge of where to
     locate the web services it needs to contact.  It can obtain these from
     several locations.  See eucalyptus-admin(7) for more information.

Eucalyptus 4.3                   July 5, 2016                   Eucalyptus 4.3
{noformat}
Code has not yet been pushed, just passed UX review.

Nice tool mr [~gholms]!

Works perfectly. I tested all the options, no issues found.
